Unlike conventional semiconductors, where their valence
bands consist of p orbitals and conduction bands consist of
s orbitals, the valence bands of 2D and 3D perovskites are
mainly composed of p orbitals of halogens hybridized with the
s orbitals of metals, while the conduction bands are emphati­
cally made of the p orbitals of metals. In lead iodide–based
perovskites, the valence band is relevant to the orbitals of I 5p
and Pb 6s, and Pb 6p orbitals for conduction band.
fore, both metal substitution and halogen doping can affect the
bandgap of perovskites to achieve the desired properties.
2D perovskites with Sn and Ge are known to have smaller
is 2.19 eV, while that of PEA
The binding energies of excitons have also been
reported to decrease from 230 to 160–190 meV for these two 2D
Recently, Zeng’s group obtained the bandgap
Ge, Sn, and Pb) by theoretical calculations.
resulted from the reduced coordination symmetry around the
cations by unbonded lone pair electrons.
It can be seen from Figure 5d
that the bandgap reduces with the increase of Sn component.
0.5, the smallest bandgap is 1.95 eV. A partial substi­
tution of Sn not only reduces the bandgap, but also improves
the conductivity, and the improvement of moisture stability
is caused by the addition of PEA with
hydrophobic groups, which is more helpful as a light­absorbing
The bandgap of 2D perovskites can also be changed by
halide substitution. Replacing iodide with bromide and
chloride will increase the bandgap of perovskite, because
the maximum value of valence band (p orbitals) is lowered
by the introduction of relatively high electronegative elem
, where Z and Y stand for I, Br, or Cl,
shown in Figure 5e,f, strong absorption peaks are observed
with narrow bandwidths, at 2.4 eV (I­only), 3.1 eV (Br­only),
and 3.7 eV (Cl­only), respectively, corresponding to a previous

and the continuous regulation of bandgap is therefore real­
ized. Compared with the single halide perovskites, the mixed
halide perovskites have inhomogeneous broader absorption
peak due to the disordered distribution of halides in inorganic
Recently, the same halide regulation of (PEA)
was reported by Zhang’s group with a highest PLQY of 46.5%

on the stoichiometric ratio, which is attributed to the reduc­
tion of dielectric and quantum confinement effects.

perovskites are all semiconductors, with a clear direct bandgap
shown in Figure 5g, where the valence band is mainly com­
posed of I 5p and a small number of Pb 6s, while the conduc­

Peng et al. reported that the bandgap of (PEA)

The recombination of free exciton is the source of narrow emis­
sion and small Stokes shift about (001) 2D lead halide perov­
skites. Stimulated by light, electrons transit from the ground
state to the excited state, leaving holes in the ground state, and
then the recombination of free exciton releases energy in the
form of fluorescence, as shown in
tunable color in the visible range and high PLQY of 2D perov­
skites are demonstrated. The luminescence with different wave­
lengths is realized through the regulation of metals (Pb and
Sn) and halogens (Cl, Br, I) of L

to the direction of lower energy from 3.08 to 2.41 eV for

high PLQY and adjusted band edge emission were reported
as demonstrated in Figure 6c. Zhang’s group
reported tunable emission of ultrathin monolayer (PEA)
from Figure 6d that the emission peak of (PEA)
at 524.0 nm with a full width at half maximum (FWHM) of
14.7 nm. When the proportion of Br increases, the emission
peak gradually shifts to blue, until (PEA)
highest PLQY of 46.5% at 409.1 nm and a narrow FWHM of
10.6 nm. Figure 6e shows the color change of (PEA)
violet to blue and finally green, under a 365 nm light excitation.
The PLQY of 2D perovskites is generally low due to the
phase impurity and traps on the film surface from the solution
